msDesc.head: Texts on prognostication; England (St Albans), before 1259

msContents.textLang: Latin with some additions in Middle English

msItem.note: Closely related to Cambridge, Magdalene College, Pepys MS. 911 (13th century, second half); for items 1–5 the present MS. and the Pepys MS. may both derive from a common exemplar (see Iafrate (2012) 61–7). MS. Digby 46, copied from the present MS. in the third quarter of the fourteenth centry, gives some idea of what is now missing from the present MS., although the question is complicated by the possibility that the Digby MS. also includes material from another source (Iafrate, op. cit., 67–74).

msItem.author: Bernardus Silvestris (?)
msItem.title: Experimentarius
msItem.note: See C. S. F. Burnett, 'What Is the Experimentarius of Bernardus Silvestris?: A Preliminary Survey of the Material', Archives d'histoire doctrinale et littéraire du moyen âge 44 (1977) 62–108; M. Brini-Savorelli, in Rivista critica di storia della filosofia 14 (1959) 306–342.
Apparently Burnett's 'Sententia II' (incomplete) (cf. Burnett, 'Experimentarius', p. 125); most of the page taken up with later additions and notes of ownership.
msItem.explicit: Que magis apparent recia vitat auis (?)

msItem.note: Burnett's 'Associated tract I', an onomantic text in the tradition of 'The Victorious and the Vanquished'
msItem.incipit: Unum et unum minor corpore vincet
Materia huius libelli est effectus et efficacia lune et aliorum planetarum
msItem.explicit: Non quia inuentor fuit sed fidelis ab arabico in latinum interpres

msItem.incipit: Primo fiat linea casualiter numero punctorum
[in blue:] De vita [in red:] Quid erit dic [in green:] Quare a sedente super [in red:] Orientalem faciem [in blue:] Turris Saturni
msItem.explicit: [in red:] 1ma [in blue:] Redi [in red:] responde [in blue:] perge ad Iudicem [in red:] fatorum [in blue with red initial:] Algargalafar [in red:] xxviij

msItem.note: Begins imperfect, lacking the first two sections due to the loss of a folio before fol. 5; a folio containing sections 15–16 also missing after fol. 10.
msItem.incipit: Venit qui compedes diuina potencia soluit
msItem.explicit: Opta que dei sunt fauebit dominus ipse

msItem.incipit: Hoc ornamentum decus est et fama ferentum
msItem.explicit: Vite solamen cupis hoc tibi det deus. Amen.

msItem.title: Prognosticon Socratis Basilei
msItem.note: See E. M. Cartelle and A. A. Guardo, Los "Libros de Suertes" Medievales: Las Sortes Sanctorum y Los Prenostica Socratis Basilei (2004), with edition of the text, pp. 250–75

msItem.rubric: Documentum subsequentis consideracionis que socratica dicitur
msItem.incipit: In prenosticis Socratis basilei que in subsequenti folio scribuntur hoc est rudimentum. Primo iaciantur casualiter puncta infra numerum denarium

msItem.note: Full-page miniature of Plato and Socrates, with later marginal addition in English.

msItem.rubric: (at bottom) Tabula consideraconis pronosticorum secundum Basileum Socratem
msItem.incipit: An erit bonum ire extra domnum vel Non
msItem.explicit: An erit bonum rem suam aliter comendare vel non.

msItem.note: Diagrams: Spera specierum (fol. 33av), Spera florum (fol. 33br), Spera fructuum (fol. 33bv, fol. 34r), Spera bestiarum (fol. 34v), Spera volatilium (fol. 35r, fol. 35v, fol. 36r) Spera ciuitatum (fol. 36v, fol. 37r, fol. 37v, fol. 38r, fol. 38v).
Answers of the 16 kings; 16 stanzas of 9 nines.
msItem.rubric: Primum locum teneant rubrice in conputacionibus | Rex turcorum
msItem.incipit: Quod uis erit et bonum tibi eueniet
msItem.explicit: Grauida pariet filiam de qua bona erit ei

msItem.title: Prenostica Pitagorice consideracionis
msItem.note: A. A. Guardo, 'Los Prenostica Pitagorice consideracionis: un libro de suertes medieval. Estudio introductorio', Studi medievali 47 (2006), 839–53.

msItem.incipit: In prenosticis pitagorice consideracionis primo iaciantur puncta casualiter sine intencione

msItem.note: Alphabetical index to the 36 questions (later addition, 15th century (?))
Full-page drawing of 'Pitagoras', with marginal texts added later (see Decoration, Additions)

msItem.incipit: Si puer viuet Vade ad Columbam
msItem.explicit: Si amissio per latrone inuenietur Vade ad arfarperet

msItem.note: Answers to the questions, 12-line stanzas each attributed to a bird, accompanied by drawings of the birds.
msItem.incipit: Iste puer viuet satis et prosperabitur in diebus suis
msItem.explicit: Debilis eris corpore et odiosus omnibus

msItem.title: Sortes duodecim patriarcharum
msItem.note: See T. C. Skeat, 'An Early Medieval 'Book of Fate': the Sortes XII Patriarcharum', Mediaeval and Renaissance Studies 3 (1954), 41–54.

msItem.incipit: De cognitacione Responde Quere in libro prophetie Ivde
msItem.explicit: De fortuna si prospera Responde Quere in libro prophetie Beniamin

msItem.rubric: Iudas Iudex Regalis confitens ueritatem. Primus Iudex.
msItem.incipit: Velle dei nosse casu non est tibi posse
msItem.explicit: Sors bene succedit aderit que mens tua credit
msItem.note: Pr. A. Boutelmy, 'Notice sur le recueil poétique du manuscrit Cotton Vitellius A xii, du British Museum', Latomus 1/4 (1937), 278–313, at 300–3

msItem.title: Quaestiones Albedaci
msItem.note: Cf. Cat. Lyell MSS., p. 98 (MS. Lyell 36, part D, item 6, fols. 75v-84). Here apparently incomplete, lacking a preliminary table and 36 questions. 36 twelve-line stanzas.
msItem.rubric: Gosal iudex primus. Qui presagus uel primicerius interpretatur
msItem.incipit: Sub fatis uita fiet diuturna beata
msItem.explicit: Eger erit sanus scias quamuis ueteranus

msItem.title: Divinacio ciceronalis
msItem.note: See A. A. Guardo, 'La Divinacio Ciceronalis: un libro de suertes medieval. Estudio introductorio', in De lo humano y lo divino en la literatura medieval: santos, ángeles y demonios, ed. Juan Paredes Núñez (2012), 17–34.

The surviving section in this MS. comprises the responses, fourteen (of originally 20) sections of 21 lines, the first line of each in red, each section attributed to sun, moon, a planet or a sign of the zodiac (Guardo's section 4). The text in MS. Digby 46 has in addition a miniature of Cicero, twenty prognostical questions, and directions for use (see Guardo).
msItem.incipit: (first line in red) Mittam te ad amicum meum et dicet tibi uerum Certe tibi dico prope est ut gaudeas et mutes fortunam

supportDesc.extent: i + 72 + i (foliated i, 1–71; 33 and 56 are double)
supportDesc.collation: Uncertain. Quires 3–8 numbered in roman numerals on the first folio (fols. 20r, 29r, 33r, 42r, 50r)

layoutDesc.layout: Layout variable according to the text: fols. 1–30, 1 col. (or tables), 28 lines; fol. 31, 2 cols., 29 lines; fols. 39r-40r, 2 cols., 30 lines; fol. 40v, 2 cols, 28 lines; fols. 43v-63v, 2 cols., 27 lines; fols. 64r-, 1 col., 21 lines

handDesc.handNote: Written by Matthew Paris, except for fols. 53r-55v.

decoDesc.decoNote:
Fine miniatures (coloured drawings). Illuminated by Matthew Paris of St. Albans, d. 1259. The MS. is mutilated. (Pächt and Alexander iii. 437, pl. XXXVIII)
'Author' portraits: fol. 2v: upper half of page, Euclid and Hermanus; fol. 31v, full page, Socrates and Plato; fol. 42r, full page, Pythagoras; fol. 52v, upper half of page, the twelve patriarchs.
Fol. 1v, lower margin, battling monk.
Fol. 2r, diagram of constellations.
Fol. 3v, marginal drawings of the seven planetary towers.
Fols. 33a-38, appropriate images in the spheres (flower, fruits, animals, birds, etc.).
Fols. 43v-52r, images of the answering birds at the head of their stanzas.
Throughout: initials in red and blue, with pen-work flourishing in alternating blue and red.

physDesc.additions: Occasional contemporary glosses. Later annotations in Middle English (fols. 31v-32r, 42r, 52v-53r, 56ar: the longer passages printed in Index of Middle English Prose: Ashmole, p. 12). Later note of missing text, fol. 59 'hic deficit versus de debito';

history.provenance: Written at St Albans Abbey, mostly by Matthew Paris (d. 1259).
A copy was made from the MS. in the third quarter of the fourteenth century (MS. Digby 46).
The Middle English annotations, which probably date from the second half of the fifteenth century, perhaps suggest that the MS. was no longer in monastic ownership.
'Thomas West writt this same anno domini 1602': otherwise unidentified (fol. 67v, cf. fol. 1r).
A copy was made from the MS. in the seventeenth century (British Library MS. Sloane 3857)

'Ex dono – Vaughan coll. En. nasi schol.' (note in the hand of Edward Lhuyd, d. 1709, fol. 1r). Not in the 1697 catalogue, so presumably entered the Ashmolean Museum between 1697 and 1709 (Summary Catalogue V.82).
history.acquisition: Transferred to the Bodleian Library in 1860.

recordHist.source: Draft description by Matthew Holford, March 2018. Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (W. H. Black, A descriptive, analytical, and critical catalogue of the manuscripts bequeathed unto the University of Oxford by Elias Ashmole Esq...., Quarto Catalogues X, 1845). Quarto Catalogue, cols. 213–14 Quarto Catalogue, cols. 215–16 Summary Catalogue, vol. 5, p. 82

availability.p: To ensure its preservation, access to this item is restricted, and readers are asked to work from reproductions and published descriptions as far as possible. If you wish to apply to see the original, please click the request button above. When your request is received, you will be asked to contact the relevant curator outlining the subject of your research, the importance of this item to that research, and the resources you have already consulted.

Otto Pächt and J. J. G. Alexander, Illuminated Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library, Oxford, III (1973), no. 437

ref.title: JONAS: Répertoire des textes et des manuscrits médiévaux d'oc et d'oïl

bibl.note: (the present MS. does not contain the Anglo-Norman Divinations, as stated, but that text is a translation of Divinacio Ciceronalis, item 6 in the present MS.)

ref.title: MLGB3: Medieval Libraries of Great Britain
